--- title: "Regression and Statistical Inference" format: html: self-contained: true toc: true theme: "cosmo" editor: visual --- # Load the Library # Load the Data & Check Dimension ```{.r .cell-code} car_prices <- readRDS("E:/Master Study/TUHH/Wise 23-24/Causal Data Science for Business Analytics/Causal_Data_Science_Data/car_prices.rds") head(car_prices) ``` `````{=html}
````` ```{.r .cell-code} dim(car_prices) ``` [1] 181 22 # data types do you see? How do numbers differ from strings regarding their data type? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} #| output: asis car_prices <- readRDS("E:/Master Study/TUHH/Wise 23-24/Causal Data Science for Business Analytics/Causal_Data_Science_Data/car_prices.rds") head(car_prices) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} str(car_prices) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> tibble [181 Ã— 22] (S3: tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #> $ aspiration : chr [1:181] "std" "std" "std" "std" ... #> $ doornumber : chr [1:181] "two" "two" "two" "four" ... #> $ carbody : chr [1:181] "convertible" "convertible" "hatchback" "sedan" ... #> $ drivewheel : chr [1:181] "rwd" "rwd" "rwd" "fwd" ... #> $ enginelocation : chr [1:181] "front" "front" "front" "front" ... #> $ wheelbase : num [1:181] 88.6 88.6 94.5 99.8 99.4 ... #> $ carlength : num [1:181] 169 169 171 177 177 ... #> $ carwidth : num [1:181] 64.1 64.1 65.5 66.2 66.4 66.3 71.4 71.4 71.4 67.9 ... #> $ carheight : num [1:181] 48.8 48.8 52.4 54.3 54.3 53.1 55.7 55.7 55.9 52 ... #> $ curbweight : num [1:181] 2548 2548 2823 2337 2824 ... #> $ enginetype : chr [1:181] "dohc" "dohc" "ohcv" "ohc" ... #> $ cylindernumber : chr [1:181] "four" "four" "six" "four" ... #> $ enginesize : num [1:181] 130 130 152 109 136 136 136 136 131 131 ... #> $ fuelsystem : chr [1:181] "mpfi" "mpfi" "mpfi" "mpfi" ... #> $ boreratio : num [1:181] 3.47 3.47 2.68 3.19 3.19 3.19 3.19 3.19 3.13 3.13 ... #> $ stroke : num [1:181] 2.68 2.68 3.47 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 ... #> $ compressionratio: num [1:181] 9 9 9 10 8 8.5 8.5 8.5 8.3 7 ... #> $ horsepower : num [1:181] 111 111 154 102 115 110 110 110 140 160 ... #> $ peakrpm : num [1:181] 5000 5000 5000 5500 5500 5500 5500 5500 5500 5500 ... #> $ citympg : num [1:181] 21 21 19 24 18 19 19 19 17 16 ... #> $ highwaympg : num [1:181] 27 27 26 30 22 25 25 25 20 22 ... #> $ price : num [1:181] 13495 16500 16500 13950 17450 ... ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} print("Numbers are described by 'num', while strings are described by 'chr'. In this dataset, another data type is also exist, which is boolean described by 'logic'") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> [1] "Numbers are described by 'num', while strings are described by 'chr'. In this dataset, another data type is also exist, which is boolean described by 'logic'" ``` ::: ::: # Run a linear regression. You want to explain what factors are relevant for the pricing of a car. ```{.r .cell-code} # Include all potential regressors lm_all <- lm(price ~ ., data = car_prices) summary(lm_all) ``` Call: lm(formula = price ~ ., data = car_prices) Residuals: Min 1Q Median 3Q Max -5662 -1120 0 798 9040 Coefficients: Estimate Std. freedom Multiple R-squared: 0.9415, Adjusted R-squared: 0.9264 F-statistic: 62.21 on 37 and 143 DF, p-value: < 2.2e-16 # Choose one regressor (Data type, Effect of changing value to the price, whether it is statistically significant ```{.r .cell-code} print("One regressor chosen is peakrpm. It has decimal (numbers) data type. Its effect on the price can be shown by its slope (coefficient). For 1 peak rpm higher, it increases the price by 2.536 unit price. The peak rpm effect on price is statistically significant, indicated by p-value much lower than <0.05. The p-value of peak rpm is 0.000108, which means it has highly significant effect on price.") ``` [1] "One regressor chosen is peakrpm. It has decimal (numbers) data type. Its effect on the price can be shown by its slope (coefficient).\n For 1 peak rpm higher, it increases the price by 2.536 unit price. The peak rpm effect on price is statistically significant, indicated by p-value much lower than <0.05.\n The p-value of peak rpm is 0.000108, which means it has highly significant effect on price." # Add a variable seat_heating to the data and assign a value TRUE for all observations. What coefficient do you get for the new variable seat_heating and how can you explain it? ```{.r .cell-code} car_prices <- car_prices %>% mutate(seat_heating = TRUE) lm_all <- lm(price ~ ., data = car_prices) summary(lm_all) ``` Call: lm(formula = price ~ ., data = car_prices) Residuals: Min 1Q Median 3Q Max -5662 -1120 0 798 9040 Coefficients: (1 not defined because of singularities) Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) (Intercept) 12999.4 599.7 21.68 <2e-16 *** seat_heatingTRUE NA NA NA NA --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Residual standard error: 8068 on 180 degrees of freedom ```{.r .cell-code} print ("Coefficient on seat heating is not available since all cars have seat heating but it doesn't increase the price. Mathematically, changes in price (as Y axis), but no changes in seat heating (as X axis) would result delta Y/ delta X not available N/A since any numbers divided by 0 is undefined.") ``` [1] "Coefficient on seat heating is not available since all cars have seat heating but it doesn't increase the price.\n Mathematically, changes in price (as Y axis), but no changes in seat heating (as X axis) would result delta Y/ delta X not available N/A since\n any numbers divided by 0 is undefined."
